thread.title: Why National Australia Bank's selling final stake in Great Western Bank
thread.title_full: Why National Australia Bank's selling final stake in Great Western Bank | afr.com

author: Clancy Yeates
title: Why National Australia Bank's selling final stake in Great Western Bank
text:
NAB's Andrew Thorburn this week said the bank had done most of the "heavy lifting" on capital. Louie Douvis Share on twitter Share on Google Plus by Clancy Yeates National Australia Bank has indicated that it will soon sell its final 28.5 per cent stake in US lender Great Western Bank.
As part of chief executive Andrew Thorburn's strategy of focusing more on the Australian and New Zealand markets, NAB has sold down two tranches in Great Western to US share investors over the past year, raising a total of more than $US800 million ($1.08 billion).
Now it has lodged paperwork with the Securities Exchange Commission signalling its intention to launch an initial public offering for the remaining 28.5 per cent stake, the bank said on Friday.
It did not say how much it expected the shares to sell for.
Bank of America Merrill Lynch, Deutsche Bank and JPMorgan are acting as book-running managers and underwriters on the deal.
The move comes as Australian banks look to asset sales as one way of raising more capital in the face of tougher regulatory demands.
NAB has the strongest capital position of the big four, with a core equity tier 1 ratio of 10 per cent, after Mr Thorburn raised $5.5 billion in equity from investors in May.
Mr Thorburn said this week that the bank had done "most of the heavy lifting" through the May raising, which he described as "a prudent, appropriate move".
 "We still believe we are well placed, and we still believe we absolutely did the right thing in May to get ahead of that," he said on Wednesday.
Alongside Great Western, the other overseas bank Mr Thorburn wants to sell is Clydesdale and Yorkshire Bank in the UK.
It is planning to spin off up to 80 per cent of Clydesdale to NAB shareholders and float the rest in the UK by the end of this year.
